section.title: 5G End-to-End Network Slice
section.t: The scope of 5G End-to-End Network Slice discussed in this document is shown in figure 1. Transport network provides connectivity between and inside RAN and CN. To support fully automated enablement an assurance of 5G E2E network slices, multiple controllers are needed to manage 5G E2E network slices in RAN, Core and Transport domains. In addition, an E2E network slice orchestrator is needed to provide coordination and control of network slices from an E2E perspective.

section.t:
Depends on Radio Access Network (RAN) deployment, one or multiple IETF network slice might be needed in 3GPP network. In the details of various IETF network slices for following RAN deployment will be discussed:
Distributed RAN Centralized RAN Cloud RAN (C-RAN)

section.title: IETF Network Slices in Distributed RAN deployment
section.t: Distributed RAN is the most common deployment of 3GPP RAN networks as shown in Figure 2-1. The radio acess network (RAN) is connected to Core network (CN) using the IETF transport network (TN1).

figure.name: IETF network slices in distributed RAN deployment

section.title: IETF Network Slices in Centralized RAN deployment
section.t: In general the RAN network consists of network functions NF1 and MF2. NF1 processes the radio signal and is connected to the transport network and NF2 transmits and receives the carrier signal that is transmitted over the air to the end user equipment (UE). In Centralized RAN as depicted in Figure 2-2, network functions NF1 and NF2 are separated by a network called fronthaul network (FH).

In this deployment a 3GPP E2E network slice contains of RAN and Core slices and IETF network slices INS1, INS2 and INS3. INS1 and INS2 are identical to Figure 2-1 and INS3 is a new IETF network slice across access network between NF1 and NF2.

figure.name: IETF network slices in centralized RAN deployment

section.title: IETF Network Slices in Cloud RAN deployment (C-RAN)
section.t: In Cloud RAN deployment, the network function NF2 is further disaggregated into real-time and non-real-time components. As shown in Figure 2-3, these disaggregated components are called CU (Central Unit) and DU (Distributed Unit) where they are connected by a new network called Midhaul network (MH).

In this deployment a single 3GPP E2E network slice contains not only RAN and 5G Core slices but IETF network slices INS1, INS2, INS3 and INS4. IETF network slices INs1, INS2 and INS3 are identical to their counterparts in centralized RAN deployment case (Refer to Figure 2-2). In this deployment a new IETF network slice INS4 connects the DUs to CUs through F1 interfaces.
